A rational and bottom-up route for assembling layered Zr(IV) phosphonate framework decorated with covalently anchored N-heterocyclic carbene NHC-Pd(II) fragment has been developed. Reaction of phosphonic acid functionalized Pd(II)-NHC precursor complex with ZrOCl2·8H2O provides easy access to a layered material with covalently anchored catalytically active Pd(II)-NHC sites. The Pd(II)-NHC functionalized Zr(IV) phosphonate showed enhanced catalytic activity in Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling reaction of both aryl bromides and chlorides with aryl boronic acid, as compared to their homogeneous counterparts. The Zr(IV) phosphonate framework imparts remarkable robustness to the Pd(II)-NHC catalyst and allowed recycling of the catalyst up to nine catalytic cycles without any major loss of catalytic activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pd-PEPPSI Zr(IV)phosphonate Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligated palladium(II) complexes are widely recognized as a versatile class of catalyst for a host of important CC coupling reactions [1,2]. C-C coupling reactions are of utmost importance for industrial application, as these reactions serve as backbone for many pharmaceutical products. Palladium catalyst in various forms such as Pd nanoparticle, Pd phosphine complex, Pd/C and Pd-NHC complexes are used in industrial scale for synthesis of different cross coupling products [3-7]. Several classes of easily preparable, air- and moisture-stable Pd(II)-NHC complexes which show high catalytic activity and selectivity under mild reaction condition have been so far developed and some of these catalysts are even commercially available [8-16]. Nevertheless, reusability of catalysts and contamination of residual palladium in products due to the homogenous nature of these catalysts remains a major challenge that needs to be addressed. Development of heterogeneous catalytic systems by anchoring Pd(II)-NHC groups onto a solid support has emerged as a potential alternative to use homogenous catalysts. In this regard, organic polymers and silicate materials have received significant interest as solid supports and several Pd(II)-NHC based catalytic systems using these materials have been reported so far [17-20]. More recently, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as a preferred choice of solid support to build heterogeneous catalyst due to their crystalline and porous nature. Several post-synthetic and pre-synthetic approaches have been developed for integrating Pd(II)-NHC moieties on MOFs, and some of these examples are structurally well-characterized, resulting into high catalytic efficacy and recyclability of the obtained catalysts [21-23]. Majority of Pd(II)-NHC group-embedded MOFs developed so far are assembled by employing carboxylate based linkers [21-23]. Nevertheless, hydrolytic stability of such carboxylate-based MOFs remains a major concern and should be addressed for industrial application of catalysts fabricated by using such MOFs as support [24-26]. In this regard, the astounding robustness of tetravalent metal organophosphonate-based frameworks is of relevance [27]. For example, layered framework structure in Zr(IV) phenyl phosphonate retains its integrity even in boiling concentrated sulphuric acid medium [28,29]. Thus, integrating catalytically active organometallic moieties on layered metal phosphonate framework is anticipated to result heterogeneous catalysts with augmented recyclability and minimal leaching of the metallic species into products. Moreover, due to layered structure of metal organophosphonates, the resulting materials are expected to have large exposed functional sites in well-ordered fashion above and below the solid support. Therefore, a better catalyst to substrate interaction is anticipated and this, in turn, is expected to enhance the catalytic efficacy. Although, metal organophosphonates have found numerous applications as support in heterogeneous catalysis, to the best of our knowledge, only one previous study has focused on covalently anchoring single site organometallic species on a metal phosphonate framework [30]. Recently, we have reported a series of Pd(II)-PEPPSI (PEPPSI = pyridine enhanced precatalyst preparation, stabilization and initiation) complexes bearing pendant phosphonate ester or phosphonic acid functionality [31]. In this study, a zirconium(IV) phosphonate framework is prepared by employing a Pd(II)-NHC complex, [Pd(L1)(py)I2] (Chart 1 ), bearing dangling phosphonic acid functionality as precursor. The catalytic efficacy as well as recyclability of the resulting layered Zr(IV) phosphonate decorated with covalently anchored Pd(II)-NHC fragment are also investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Starting materials were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. Solvents were purified by conventional techniques and distilled prior to use. The precursor Pd-PEPPSI complex, [Pd(L1)(py)I2], containing phosphonic acid functionality, RPO3H2 was prepared by following a method published by our group [31,32]. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin Elmer Model PR 2400 series II elemental analyser. Fourier transformed infrared spectra from 400 to 4000 cm-1 were recorded on Perkin Elmer Frontier MIR-FIR FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed with the help of Thermal analyser (Model TGA-50 & DSC-60, Shimadzu). ICP-OES analysis was carried out using Perkin Elmer Optima 2100 DV Optical Emission Spectroscopy analyser. The surface area and pore size distribution of the compound was analyzed using BET surface analyser (QUANTACHROME NOVA 1000E). The field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) analyses were carried out using a Carl Zeiss ΣIGMA SEM, equipped with an Energy-Dispersive X-ray analyser. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was recorded using JEOL JEM-2100 Plus Electron Microscope. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded on a Rigaku Multiflex instrument using a nickel-filtered CuKα (0.15418 nm) radiation source and scintillation counter detector. Magic angle spinning NMR (MAS NMR) of 13C and 31P were recorded with AVANCE III 500 WB spectrometer using adamantane (δ = 38 ppm) and H3PO4 (δ = 0 ppm) as references, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) analyses were performed in KRATOS Axis ultra DLD spectrometer and Thermofisher Scientific Nexsa base spectrometer using Al Kα (1486.6 eV) radiation source. 2.2 Synthesis of [Zr(RPO3)1.62(OH)0.76].nH2O (1) ZrOCl2·8H2O (24 mg, 0.072 mmol) and [Pd(L1)(py)I2] (50 mg, 0.072 mmol) were dissolved in 12 mL H2O: n-propanol (1:3) solution separately and stirred to obtain a clear solution. Both solutions were mixed together in the presence of pyridine (200 μL) after which an immediate precipitation was observed. The resulting mixture was further stirred at 40 °C for 3 days. The residue obtained was washed several times with n-propanol, followed by Et2O to obtain the pale-yellow powder. The product was finally dried in air. Yield: 75 mg (49 % based on Zr) Elemental analysis % found (calculated) for C25.92H41.92I3.24N4.86O12.24P1.62Pd1.62Zr: C 23.12 (23.19 %), H 3.31 (3.15 %), N 4.93 (5.07 %), P 3.63 (3.74 %), Zr 6.53 (6.80 %), Pd 12.47 (12.84 %). FT-IR: (KBr, cm-1): 3436(br), 2924(s), 2852(m), 1632(s), 1514(w), 1015(s), 851(w), 563(w). TGA (10 °C/minute under air): Temperature range (% weight loss): 110 °C (14 %); 203–344 °C (7 %); 457 (22 %). 2.3 Typical procedure for suzuki-miyaura cross-coupling reaction 0.24 mmol of the aryl boronic acid and 0.2 mmol of aryl chloride/bromide were dissolved in 4 mL of isopropanol/water (3:1) solution. To the above solution, 0.4 mmol of potassium carbonate and 5 mg (0.01 mol%) of the catalyst 1 were added and the reaction mixture was heated at 60 °C temperature for 2 h under N2 atmosphere. The progress of the reaction was monitored by using thin layer chromatography. Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was removed by centrifugation. The reaction mixtures were subjected to GC–MS analysis to identify the products and further confirmed by the 1H NMR of the products. The products were extracted by using hexane and dried over Na2SO4 and purified by column chromatography. To investigate the role of the solvents and the base used in the reaction mixture, test reactions have been carried out using different solvents and bases. It has been found that the use of isopropanol/water (3:1) solution and K2CO3 as base at 60 °C condition gives the maximum yield under N2 atmosphere. For reusability test, reaction of 4‑bromotoluene and phenyl boronic acid in presence of isopropanol/water (3:1) solvent and K2CO3 as base at 60 °C under N2 atmosphere was taken as model reaction. Each reaction was carried out for two hours time and after completion of each cycle, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and washed several time with isopropanol solution and then used for next catalytic cycle directly. 2.4 Hot filtration test To investigate the leaching of the catalyst in the reaction medium, initially 4‐bromotoluene and phenyl boronic acid was used as reactant in 3:1 i PrOH:H2O solution using 5 mg of the catalyst at 60 °C. The reaction mixture was filtered through a Whatman filter paper under hot condition which was followed by centrifugation to ensure the complete removal of any solid catalyst after 0.5 h of reaction. Then the reaction mixture was further allowed to reflux. The reaction was monitored using TLC. 2.5 Three phase test Initially, aminopropyl-modified Silica (SiO2 C3H6NH2) was prepared by using a reported procedure with slight modification [33]. To a suspension of SiO2 (100–200 mesh size, 3 g) in dry toluene a solution of 3‐Aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS) (4.8 ml, 27 mmol) and pyridine (3 ml, 36.9 mmol) were added dropwise through a dropping funnel under N2 atmosphere. The resulting mixture was refluxed for 24 hrs. After that, the suspension was filtered and Soxhlet extracted with CH2Cl2 for another 24 hrs. The resulting solid was dried under vacuum at room temperature to obtain the product as white powder. Yield: 3.25 g; FT-IR: 3448 (b), 2927 (w, b), 1638 (w, b), 1088 (s), 791 (s), 574 (w), 466(s). For carrying out the three phase test, a procedure developed by Corma et al. was adopted [34]. For this purpose, a solid supported aryl bromide was initially prepared. A solution of 4‐Bromobenzoylchloride (0.80 g, 3.6 mmol) was dissolved in dry THF (10 ml) in a round bottom flask with aminopropyl trimethoxy silane modified silica (SiO2 C3H6NH2) (1 g) and pyridine (404 μL, 5 mmol) under N2 atmosphere. The mixture was stirred for 12 hrs at 40 °C after which the resulting suspension was filtered and washed 3 times by 20 ml 5 % (v/v) HCl in water, followed by 20 ml of 0.2 M aqueous K2CO3, then washed two times with distilled water followed by 20 ml of ethanol. The solid was finally washed with large excess of CH2Cl2 and finally dried in air. 1.2 g solid is recovered and assigned as BrPhCONHC3H6@SiO2. FT-IR: 3411 (b), 2926 (w, b), 1720 (w), 1262(s), 1090 (s). In the next step, 4-bromotoluene (0.2 mmol), phenyl boronic acid (0.24 mmol), K2CO3 (0.25 mmol) in i PrOH:H2O (3:1) in presence of catalyst 1 (5 mg, 0.01 mol%) and BrPhCONHC3H6@SiO2 (200 mg) were refluxed at 60 °C for 2 h. After this the suspension was analyzed by TLC and the solid was separated under vacuum in hot condition, washed with i PrOH and finally extracted with CH2Cl2. Another reaction carried out under the same reaction condition but without the addition of 4-bromotoluene to the reaction medium. In this case also the solid was recovered by hot filtration followed by washing with i PrOH, and finally extracted with CH2Cl2. The recovered solids from both the reaction mixtures were hydrolyzed with 2 M KOH prepared in ethanol-water mixture at 90 °C for 3 days. The resulting solution was neutralized with 10 % HCl v/v (9.1 ml), extracted with CH2Cl2 followed by ethyl acetate, concentrated, and the resulting mixture was analyzed by 1H NMR. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of [Zr(RPO3)1.62(OH)0.76].nH2O (1) We have recently reported a series of Pd(II)-PEPPSI complexes featuring dangling phosphonate ester or phosphonic acid functional groups [31]. These, complexes show reasonably good catalytic activity in Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling reaction involving aryl chlorides and aryl bromides with aryl boronic acids under mild reaction conditions. Further, reaction of the precursor imidazolium ligand bearing phosphonic acid functionality with Zr(IV) salt affords layered Zr(IV) phosphonate framework where covalently linked imidazolium groups are uniformly present on the surface [32]. By employing the Pd(II)-PEPPSI complex bearing phosphonic acid functionality as the precursor ligand, [Pd(L1)(py)I2], we have now accessed a layered zirconium(IV) phosphonate framework uniformly decorated with covalently anchored Pd(II)-PEPPSI groups. Thus, reaction of the benzyl phosphonate, RPO(OH)2 (R= Pd(II)-PEPPSI fragment shown in Scheme 1 ) bearing a dangling Pd(II)-PEPPSI group with ZrOCl2·8H2O in presence of pyridine resulted a zirconium(IV) phosphonate, [Zr(RPO3)1.62(OH)0.76].nH2O (1) as a yellow powder in near quantitative yield (Scheme 1). Elemental analysis, inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and solid-state 31P NMR results conform well with the given formulation of the Zr(IV) phosphonate (see ESI). Intense signal observed at 1015 cm-1 in the FT-IR spectrum of 1 is attributed to the Zr-O-P stretching frequency, which confirms the formation of the Zr(IV) phosphonate framework [23]. Further, peak observed at 567 cm-1 corresponds to the Pd-C stretching vibration and thus confirms the stability of the Pd-PEPPSI metalloligand upon complexation with zirconium (IV). Absence of any peak in the 2260–2340 cm-1 region suggested the absence of any free P-OH group in the coordinated phosphonate ligand (Figure S1) [35]. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 shows initial weight loss of 14 %, on heating up to 110 °C, which can be attributed to loss of occluded solvent molecules in the material. Thereafter, a gradual weight loss of 7 % was observed in the temperature range 203–344 °C. The material finally degrades above 457 °C where a rapid weight loss is observed (Figure S2). Powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 1 is characteristic of layered metal phosphonates and show two major peaks at 2θ = 10.9° and 24.4 ° (Fig. 1 a) [36]. These peaks corresponding to the (002) and (110) plane of α-ZrP framework. A slight shift towards the lower 2θ value is observed in case of the peak 2θ =10.9° corresponding to the (002) plane owing to the increase in interplanar distance due to increase in the ligand size (JCPDS 34–0127) [37,38]. Powder X-ray diffraction pattern of 1 does not show any peak in the region of 2θ=39° even after prolonged exposure of the sample to air. This rules out the formation of metallic palladium and indicates the integrity of the Pd-PEPPSI group covalently anchored to the Zr(IV) phosphonate support. Solid state cross-polarization magic angle spinning 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (CP MAS 13C NMR) and 31P MAS NMR data of 1 correspond well with earlier reported solution NMR results of the precursor Pd-PEPPSI metalloligand, RPO3H2 [31]. This establishes the integrity of the Pd(II)-PEPPSI metalloligand upon complexation with zirconium(IV). Peaks observed at chemical shifts δ 63.8 and δ 39.2 ppm in the 13C CP MAS NMR spectrum are assigned to the benzyl and methyl carbon atoms present in 1, respectively. Peaks in the aromatic region at δ 152.6, 138.2 and 125.1 ppm correspond to the carbon atoms of the benzene and pyridine moiety present in the parent ligand (Figure S3). Further, the peak observed at δ 165.3 ppm can be attributed to the carbene carbon of the Pd-PEPPSI metalloligand in 1. 31P MAS NMR spectral analysis show only one distinct peak at δ 15.7 ppm, indicating that the phosphonate group in 1 is present in completely deprotonated RPO3 form (Fig. 1 b). The chemical shift observed for the phosphorous atom in 1 is consistent with the chemical shift observed in case of earlier reported zirconium benzyl phosphonate frameworks [32]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of 1 was carried out to get detailed information regarding the electronic environment of the elements present in the zirconium phosphonate framework. The overall XPS spectrum of 1 shows signal for all the constituent elements present in the framework (Figure S4). Peaks observed at 133.0 eV and 135.8 eV correspond to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 electrons of phosphorus in pentavalent state (Fig. 2 a) [39]. Deconvolution of the broad peak observed in the Zr(IV) 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 region reveals the presence of four peaks at 182.2, 184.5, 184.6 and 187.0 eV, which can be attributed to the presence of Zr(IV) present in two different types of chemical environment (Fig. 2 b). Peaks observed in higher binding energy range can be assigned to Zr(IV) centers coordinated to phosphonate ligand [40,41] while the other set of peaks observed in lower binding energy range are due to presence of Zr(IV) ions coordinated to -OH groups [42]. Four peaks are observed in the C1s region of XPS spectrum of 1 at 284.6 eV, 286.2 eV, 288.5 eV and 292.6 eV. The peak at 284.6 eV is the characteristic peak of the carbon atoms involved in CC and CH bond [43,44], whereas peaks observed at 286.2 eV and 288.5 eV peaks correspond to the carbon atom associated with CN and C-P linkage respectively [45,46]. The C1s binding energy of the carbene carbon atom is observed at 292.6 eV which compares well with the reported values (Fig. 2 c) [47]. Signal of N1s electron of nitrogen atom in CN bond is observed at 400.5 eV, whereas N1s electron involved in Pd-N interaction appears at 403.1 eV (Figure S5) [48]. Incidentally, the binding energies of zirconium(IV) 2p and palladium(II) 3d electrons fall in the same range [49]. Therefore, four peaks at 333.3 eV, 336 eV, 342.2 eV and 346.6 eV were observed in this binding energy range. After deconvolution, peaks at 333.3 eV and 346.6 eV are assigned to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 electrons of tetravalent zirconium, whereas signals at 336.9 eV and 342.2 eV are attributed to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 electron of palladium in +2 oxidation state. No peaks were observed for 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 electron of palladium in zero oxidation state (Fig. 2 d). This further confirms the stability of the Pd-PEPPSI metalloligand upon formation of the framework. Binding energy corresponding to the O1s shows three peaks at 530.7 eV, 533.5 eV and 535.9 eV due to the binding interaction Zr-O, Zr-OH and P-O, respectively (Figure S6) [37,49,50]. The peaks at 618.8 eV and 630.3 eV can be assigned to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 electrons of iodine present in the Pd-PEPPSI complex (Figure S7) [51]. Thus, the XPS data of 1 confirm the presence of all constituent elements in expected oxidation state and conform well to its proposed formulation. The surface morphology of the framework analysed by scanning electron microscopic (SEM) revealed that it has layered structures where the layers are stacked over each other. Moreover, particles of random shapes and sizes are present (Fig. 3 ). EDS analysis revealed the presence of all the desired elements in the framework (Figure S8). To get detailed morphological evidence of the synthesised material it was further investigated with HRTEM analysis. The HRTEM images depicted the porous nature of the material. Pore size distribution in the range of 30–50 nm can be observed from the TEM images. These pores can act as active site for the catalytic reactions to takes place. The EDS data is also concordant with the results obtained from the SEM-EDS analysis (Figure S9). The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm shows a type IV pattern with H2 hysteresis loop generally observed for compounds having mesoporous pores (Figure S10). This finding is also supported by the HRTEM images where a pore distribution of 30–50 nm can be observed. BET surface area of 1 is found to be 31.8 m²/g (Figure S11). 3.2 Suzuki –Miyaura cross coupling reaction We have explored the catalytic efficacy of 1 in Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling reaction of aryl boronic acid with both aryl chlorides and aryl bromides. Optimisation of the reaction conditions were carried out by investigating the coupling of p‑bromotoluene with phenyl boronic acid. Initially, the effect of solvent was studied by performing the coupling reaction in different solvent media e.g. dimethylformamide (DMF), DMF/tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), isopropanol, isopropanol-water mixture, ethanol-water mixture, THF and n-propanol. Among all the solvent systems screened, the cross-coupling reaction afforded highest yield in isopropanol ( i PrOH)-water mixture and a 3:1 i PrOH-water mixture at temperature of 60 °C is found to be the optimum reaction condition. The effects of different bases on cross-coupling biaryl product yield were also studied by performing the reaction in the presence of various bases like KOH, NaOH, Na2CO3, Cs2CO3 and K2CO3 (Table S1). All the bases investigated during our study resulted moderate-to-good yield, while best yield of 95 % was obtained when K2CO3 was used. Thus, the optimized reaction condition which gave highest yield in case of the model reaction is isopropanol-water (3:1) as solvent and in the presence of K2CO3 as base at 60 °C using 0.01 mol% of the catalyst in 2 h time under N2 atmosphere. Under the optimized reaction condition, Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions between various substituted aryl chlorides and aryl bromides along with different substituted boronic acids were investigated (Table 1 ). Up to 90 % isolated yield of cross-coupling product is obtained even when aryl chlorides are used as substrates revealing the high catalytic efficacy of the present catalyst. Electronic effect of the substituents on the yield of cross-coupling product was studied and higher yields are observed when electron donating substituents are present on the substrates. Reactions of 1-bromonapthelene with phenyl boronic acid give 95 % reaction yield with no homocoupling product. The activity of the catalyst was also studied with electron withdrawing substituent like –CN with both aryl chlorides and aryl bromides. Reactions of tolyl boronic with para and meta chloro benzonitrile give 88 % and 82 % yield, respectively, while reaction of tolyl boronic acid with para and meta bromo substituted benzonitriles resulted in 99 % and 95% yield of the respective cross-coupling product without formation of any homocoupling product. Thus, the results of cross-coupling reactions with various substituted aryl halides and boronic acid established that the catalyst is active in presence of both electron donating and withdrawing substituents. We have earlier investigated the catalytic efficacy of the precursor Pd-PEPPSI complex and two other related Pd(II)-NHC complexes in Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling reaction of aryl halides with aryl boronic acid [31]. The catalytic activity of the present heterogeneous catalyst, 1 in Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling reaction of phenyl boronic acid with 4‑chlorotoluene is compared with its homogeneous counterparts. Prominent increase in catalytic efficacy is observed in case of the heterogeneous catalyst as higher yield of the cross-coupling product is obtained for a 25 times lower catalyst loading and a shorter reaction time under otherwise same reaction conditions (Table 2 ). Efficiency of the reported catalyst 1 is compared with other reported heterogeneous Pd-NHC catalyst for coupling of aryl chlorides with boronic acid in Table 2. While most of the earlier reported catalyst showed longer reaction time along with significant requirement of catalyst (mol %) for carrying out the reaction, this catalyst can give better yield in lower reaction time in presence of catalyst loading as low as 0.01 %. Further, the recyclability of the heterogeneous catalyst 1 was evaluated by employing 4-bromotoluene and phenyl boronic acid as substrates. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed with isopropanol and used directly in the next catalytic cycle. The catalyst was found to be active for nine catalytic cycles without any significant loss of reactivity (Fig. 4 ). During the recyclability test, slight change in colour of the catalyst was observed after third catalytic cycle. But the catalytic activity is not affected significantly by this process and, therefore, the catalytic reaction was repeated for another six cycles. To explore the heterogeneity of the catalytic system, hot filtration test was performed for 1 catalyzed cross-coupling reaction of 4-bromotolouene with phenyl boronic acid. The ongoing reaction mixture was filtered under hot condition after 30 min and the reaction was continued using the filtrate. No appreciable increment in product formation was observed upon removal of the catalyst. This rules out the formation of any soluble palladium species through leaching of palladium sites from 1 during the course of catalytic reaction and establishes the heterogeneous nature of the catalytic system. To further investigate the heterogeneity of the catalyst, three phase test has been carried out by adopting a previously described procedure [40]. For this, 4‐bromobenzoylchloride was covalently immobilized on modified silica to synthesize a silica supported aryl bromide substrate, BrPhCONHC3H6@SiO2. Suzuki coupling reaction was carried out in presence of supported aryl bromide BrPhCONHC3H6@SiO2, catalyst 1 and phenyl boronic acid which are in three different phases. 4‑bromotoluene was added as an active species to the reaction medium, while keeping the other reaction condition unchanged. If the catalytic system remains heterogeneous and no palladium leaching occurs during the reaction, the supported aryl bromide will not participate in the cross-coupling reaction. During the three phase test, the phenyl boronic acid reacts with 4-bromotoluene to yield 94 % cross coupling product. However, the recovered aryl bromide from the silica surface did not show any evidence of cross coupling reaction which is established by 1H NMR analysis (Figure S37 & S38). The integrity of the catalyst after ninth catalytic cycle was investigated by the FT-IR and powder X-ray diffraction analysis. XPS analysis of the used catalyst was also performed to investigate the integrity of the catalyst after 9th catalytic cycle (Fig. 4). The FT-IR spectrum and powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the catalyst recovered after ninth catalytic cycle do not show any significant variation as compared to the as-synthesized 1. Most-importantly, absence of any peak near 2θ=39° in the powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the used catalyst shows absence of metallic palladium and integrity of the dangling Pd(II)-PEPPSI groups even after 9th catalytic cycle (Fig. 5 a). On further analysis of the catalyst 1 with XPS data, it was observed that the catalyst partially decomposed after 9th catalytic cycle. In the XPS spectra for Pd 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 two set of peaks appeared at 342.7 eV and 337.4 eV corresponding to the 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 electrons respectively for Pd in +2 oxidation state while peaks at 340.1 eV and 334.6 eV appeared for 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 respectively for Pd in zero oxidation state (Fig. 5 b). Although this reduction of Pd(II) to Pd(0) is not evident from the powder X-ray diffraction analysis, it can be observed from the XPS data [60]. Partial decomposition of reactive Pd-PEPPSI during catalysis is well documented [61-63]. A typical mechanism for Suzuki cross coupling reaction with oxidative addition, transmetalation followed by reduction elimination can be predicated for the reaction. Previous reports from similar Pd-NHC catalyst suggested that the reduction of PdII to Pd0 occurs quickly, which is then followed by dissociation of the pyridine group. The transmetalation step appears to be the rate determining step for reactions catalyzed by Pd-NHC catalyst in the presence of phenyl boronic acid as the more active nucleophile. During the catalytic cycle, pyridine group dissociate from or associate to the Pd0-NHC complex. This association dissociation mechanism may also be the reason of slow formation of palladium black, which intern extend the catalytic lifetime and also can produce higher yield [64]. Along with that the microporous heterogenous zirconium support material acts as a protecting surface to accommodate the reduce Pd0 on its surface, which further prevent the leaching of the catalyst. The homogenous Pd-PEPSSI precursor complex as well as other related Pd(II)-NHC complexes listed in Table 2 . The homogenous Pd-PEPSSI precursor complex cannot be recovered after catalytic reaction is complete and undergo decomposition at reaction temperature above 60 °C. The unique recyclability and robustness of the present heterogenous Pd(II)-PEPPSI catalytic system can be attributed to zirconium phosphonate solid support. 4 Conclusion A bottom up route to design covalently anchored Pd(II)-NHC decorated on both surfaces of layered Zr(IV) phosphonate is described. Post synthetic modification of solid surfaces can lead to non-uniform distribution of the active sites along with possibility of formation of palladium nanoparticle. The present pre-synthetic modification ensure uniform arrangement of catalytically active Pd(II)-NHC sites over Zr(IV) phosphonate layer without the formation of any nanoparticle. The catalyst shows remarkable activity for Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling reaction of aryl bromides as well as inactive aryl chlorides with different boronic acids leading up to 99 % yield of desired cross-coupling products. The intrinsic robust character of the solid support as compared to conventional metal organic framework-based supports afford reusability of the catalyst up to nine catalytic cycles without any significant loss of activity. Thus, the simple and rational methodology adopted here to anchor organometallic fragment on the surface of Zr(IV) fragment is expected to provide easy access to highly active yet robust and recyclable heterogeneous organometallic catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A rational and bottom-up route for assembling layered Zr(IV) phosphonate framework decorated with covalently anchored N-heterocyclic carbene NHC-Pd(II) fragment has been developed. Reaction of phosphonic acid functionalized Pd(II)-NHC precursor complex with ZrOCl2·8H2O provides easy access to a layered material with covalently anchored catalytically active Pd(II)-NHC sites. The Pd(II)-NHC functionalized Zr(IV) phosphonate showed enhanced catalytic activity in Suzuki-Miyaura cross coupling reaction of both aryl bromides and chlorides with aryl boronic acid, as compared to their homogeneous counterparts. The Zr(IV) phosphonate framework imparts remarkable robustness to the Pd(II)-NHC catalyst and allowed recycling of the catalyst up to nine catalytic cycles without any major loss of catalytic activity.
